moves.1. e4: This is an unrated game with Brigade Commander. Although I had the advantage at various points, the game was extremely sharp and I lost my way in the complications.
moves.1... e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Bc4 Nc6: This is one of the strongest replies. Black retains the option of Qh4+ while developing.
moves.4. d4: An alternative is Nf3 Nf6 Nd3 Bg5 and Black stands well. This line produces more complications.
moves.4... Qh4+ 5. Kf1 Nf6 6. Nf3: White needs to drive the Q back with tempo.
moves.6... Qh6: This is a good spot for the Q.
moves.7. Nc3 Be7: Here ...Bb5 is probably slightly more active. But Black has a good game.
moves.8. e5: Necessary to try and get some sort of attack going.
moves.8... Nh5 9. Nd5: ! This is the only active move otherwise Black simply consolidates.
moves.10... g5 11. g4: This is necessary to maintain the initiative.
moves.11... fxg3 e.p. 12. hxg3 d6: !? Black wants to break up the pawns. However the GK computer suggests Rg8 13. Ke1 Na5 14. Bd3 d6 15. g4 Be6 16. Nxc7+ Bxc7 17. gxh5 dxe5 18. Rxg5 Rxg5 19. Bxg5.
moves.13. g4: I thought this was stronger than Nxg5. I analyzed it and thought that I was trading 2 pcs for Rook and pawn. However, the GK computer considers that the best move: 13. Nxg5 Bxg5 14. Nxc7+ Ke7 15. Nxa8 Bxc1 16. Qxc1 Qxc1+ 17. Rxc1 Bh3+ 18. Kf2 Rxa8 19. exd6+ Kxd6 20. Rh1 Bg4 21. Bxf7.
moves.13... Nf4 14. Nxf4: I did not want to exchange the advanced N but at least I double the Black pawns.
moves.14... gxf4 15. exd6: ?! White must open lines. However g5! as suggested by BC seems better. After say Qh6+ Kf2 White has good prospects.
moves.15... Qxd6 16. Qd2: At this point I thought I had a good game.
moves.16... h5: The GK computer does not favor this move, but I am forced to take. It prefers … Bf6 17. d5 Ne5 18. Qe2 Qe7 19. Bxf4 Bxg4 20. Bb5+ c6 21. dxc6 Bh3+ 22. Kf2 Nxc6 23. Bxc6+ bxc6 24. Be5 Be6 25. Bxf6 Qxf6, with only a tiny advantage for White.
moves.17. gxh5 Bf6 18. c3: I thought this was best, because I feared Qxf4 Qxf4 Bxf4 Nxd5. The GK computer prefers that line but seems to overlook that the Q exchange is good for Black.
moves.18... Be6: At this point I think I have a good game. GK computer considers Bh3 stronger, … Bh3+ 19. Kf2 O-O-O 20. Qxf4 Rxh5 21. Qxd6 Rxd6 22. Ng5 Bxg5 23. Bxg5 Be6 24. Bxe6+ Rxe6 25. Bf4 Kd7 with an even game.
moves.20... O-O-O 21. Ng5: ? This is where I go astray, missing the possibility of a sac on d5. As BC pointed out, after 21. h6! (GK gives Be7 22. Kf2 Bd6 23. Qg4 f5 24. Qg6 Qd7 25. Qg7 f4 26. Qxd7+ Rxd7 27. Rg6 Re7) White is much better.
moves.22... Bxd4+: Crunch! Nxd5 would work as well, White's king is now exposed and Black gains and advantage.
moves.23. cxd4 Nxd4 24. Qg4+: ?? This is the losing blunder, I simply missed that f5 is possible. After the more patient 24. Re1 Qc2+ 25. Qd2 Rxh5 26. Qxc2 Nxc2 27. Bf4 Rg8 28. Ne4 Nxa1 29. Rxa1 Rf5 30. Kf3 Rd5 (GK Computer) White can hold on.
moves.24... f5: At this point I realized it was time to resign, but I decided to play on for a couple moves.
moves.25. Qf4 Qe2+ 26. Kg3 Rxh5 27. Rg2 Qe1+ 2: ? Allows mate or even Ne7+ forking K and Q. The mate is 28. Rf2 Qg1+ 29. Rg2 Ne2+ 30. Kf3 Qf1+ 31. Ke3 Nxf4 32. Rf2 Ng2+ 33. Kf3 Rd3+ 34. Be3 Rxe3#
